docs.snippet: Dr. William B. Guthrie, Professor of Political Science of the College of the City of New York, said yesterday in an address at the Pi Epsilon Phi fraternity house, 320 West 137th Street, that the movement in Congress to pass a law forbidding citiz...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. William B. Guthrie, Professor of Political Science of the College of the City of New York, said yesterday in an address at the Pi Epsilon Phi fraternity house, 320 West 137th Street, that the movement in Congress to pass a law forbidding citizens of the United States to travel on armed ships would have been in conflict with the Constitution of the United States, which guarantees to citizens the right to bear arms.
docs.abstract: speaks at Pi Epsilon Phi fraternity house on armed liner issue

headline.main: CAN'T BAN ARMED SHIPS.; Dr. W.B. Guthrie Says Constitution Gives Us Right to Travel on Them.

docs.snippet: The State Department's move to withhold passports from members of the Communist party was an inevitable result of the Supreme Court decision requiring the party to register under the Internal Security Act of 1950. The act makes it a crime for memb...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department's move to withhold passports from members of the Communist party was an inevitable result of the Supreme Court decision requiring the party to register under the Internal Security Act of 1950. The act makes it a crime for members of any group under a registration order to use, or even apply for, a passport.
docs.abstract: ed on new laws queries wisdom of requiring Communist party members to remain within US
